Lesson Narrative

In this lesson, students apply what they learned about transforming expressions into factored form to make sense of quadratic equations and persevere in solving them. They see that rearranging equations so that one side of the equal sign is 0, rewriting the expression in factored form, and then using the zero product property make it possible to solve equations that they previously could only solve by graphing. These steps also allow them to easily see—without graphing and without necessarily completing the solving process—the number of solutions that the equations have.

Learning Goals (Teacher Facing)

Students will be able to:

  • Recognize that the number of solutions to a quadratic equation can be revealed when the equation is written as expression in factored form \(=0\).
  • Use factored form and the zero product property to solve quadratic equations.

Learning Targets (Student Facing)

  • Rearrange a quadratic equation to be written as expression in factored form \(=0\) and find the solutions.
  • Recognize quadratic equations that have zero, one, or two solutions when they are written in factored form.

Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills (TEKS)


TEKS

Explanation of Coverage

A8(A) solve quadratic equations having real solutions by factoring, taking square roots, completing the square, and applying the quadratic formula.

Partial coverage: Lesson provides content that covers part of this TEKS. The parts that are covered have been underlined.

Lesson Activities

Here are the instructional activities for the lesson:

  • 8.9.1: Finding a Solution through Substitution
  • 8.9.2: Using Factored Form and the Zero Product Property to Solve Quadratic Equations
    • 8.9.2: Self Check
    • 8.9.2: Additional Resources
  • 8.9.3: Write an Equation to Represent a Quadratic Function with Only One Solution
    • 8.9.3: Self Check
    • 8.9.3: Additional Resources
  • 8.9.4: Solving More Quadratic Equations

Students will also complete a series of problems in the 8.9.5: Practice.

Required Materials

  • Paper and pencil
  • Graphing technology

Required Preparation

  • Acquire devices that can run Desmos (recommended) or other graphing technology. It is ideal if each student has their own device.

Lesson Vocabulary

During this lesson, it is important to:

  • Familiarize students with the vocabulary words they will see throughout the lesson.
  • Encourage students to look for these words and notice their use and meanings.
  • Encourage students to use key vocabulary words in “math talk” and their written and oral explanations.
  • Utilize a word wall. Sample cards are located here: Mathematics Vocabulary Word Wall Cards.

Vocabulary words that are emphasized in this lesson:

Previous Vocabulary

New Vocabulary
  • quadratic equation
  • quadratic function
  • factored form (of a quadratic expression)
  • standard form (of a quadratic expression)
  • variable
  • root
  • double root
  • zero product property
  • zero of the function
  • none
